text:
- [Vishal] Hello, everyone,
I'm Vishal Jakharia.
I'm a cloud support engineer at AWS,
and I'm one of the Amazon Cognito
subject matter expert here.

I'm excited to introduce
a new password reuse
prevention feature that has been added
to Amazon Cognito service.
This feature has been introduced as a part
of advanced security feature,

so if you have an advanced
security feature enabled
in your Amazon Cognito user pool,
then you can prevent your users
to reuse the previously used password.
By default, Amazon Cognito password policy

allows you to set up a minimum
length for the password,
and it allows you to set up a specific
character requirement for the password.

If you have enabled an
advanced security feature
in Amazon Cognito user pool,
then you can prevent your users
to reuse the previously used password.
Amazon Cognito advanced security feature
provides an enhanced protection

against compromised credential
and account takeover risk.

Whenever user is trying to
perform sign in, sign up,
or for password activity,

at the time, Amazon
Cognito identifies the risk
associated with the user activity
by checking the compromised credential

against internal and
external repositories,
and identifying the account takeover
based on potentially suspicious actions
and credential stuffing attacks.
So it provides your users protection
against compromised credential
and account takeover activity.
As a part of this new feature,
Amazon Cognito prevent your user
to reuse the previously used password.

Amazon Cognito can store up
to 24 previous passwords,

so whenever user is trying
to perform forgot password
or the change password,
or user is trying to reset their password,

and if user is trying to set
the previously used password,
then Amazon Cognito will prevent that user
to reuse the same password.
Password reuse is a common habit,
and it possesses significant risk

to your customer's online
security and privacy.

Using same or similar password
across different websites
or account can expose your customer
to potential vulnerabilities,
such as account takeover attack.
It is important to advise your customer
to adopt strong and unique password

for each of their accounts in
order to effectively safeguard
their personal information and data.
To address this concerned risk,
Amazon Cognito has introduced password use
prevention feature.
Now, we will see how we can configure
the password use prevention policy
in your Amazon Cognito user pool.

I have attached user pool
created in Amazon Cognito.
So in order to set up a password policy,

we need to go to Sign-In
Experience tab of User Pool.

Here you have an option
to add a password policy.

Default Cognito password
policy includes minimum length
of added characters,

and there is a specific
requirement for the character,

but in order to customize
the password policy,
we need to go to Custom tab.

Here you can set up a minimum
length for the password,

and you can specify the
character requirement
for your password.

This is the new feature
that has been introduced

by Amazon Cognito service
to prevent the use
of previous password.

Currently, this feature
has been disabled for me,

because I do not have
advanced security feature
enabled in my user pool,

so in order to prevent the
use of previous password,

we need to enable
advanced security feature.
So let's enable advanced security feature
for this user pool.

So now, I'm going to
Advanced Security tab,
and here, I have an option to activate
advanced security feature.

So now, I have advanced
security feature activated
for this particular user pool,

and now, I'm going back
to Sign-In Experience tab
in order to customize my password policy.

So now, I have this Prevent
Reuse of Password feature
has been enabled for my user pool.

So you can set up any
value between zero and 24.

Amazon Cognito stores up to
24 previously used password
for a user,
so if user will try to reset password,
and if user will try to reuse any
of previously used password,
then it'll prevent user to set it up.
So for the demo purpose, let's say,
I'm setting this value as a file,

so Amazon Cognito will save
five password for the users,

five previously used
password for the users,

and it will prevent users to
set the same password again.

This is how you can
configure the Prevent Reuse

of Previous Password for
Amazon Cognito user pool.
In order to test this feature,
I created one test user in my user pool
with the username as a demo,

and it has a current status
as a Force Change Password.

I will try to sign in
with this particular user,

and I will try to change
the password for this user.
By creation of this user,

I've set one initial
password for the user,
so while changing the password,
I will try to use the same password.
So it should prevent me,
because we have enabled Prevent Reuse
of Previous Password in our user pool.
This is my hosted UI screen,

and now, I'm trying to
log in with this user.
(keyboard clicking)
It is asking me to change the password,

because user status is
Force Change Password.
So I'm setting the same password
which I've used while user creation,

so it should prevent me
using the same password.
(keyboard clicking)
So now, I got an error that password
has previously been used.
This is an absolute error,

because we have set up a
Prevent Reuse of Password
in our Cognito user pool.

This is how Prevent Reuse of
Previous Password functionality
works in Amazon Cognito user pool.
Thank you.
